•   About Radia    

Thanks for trying Radia.

 

Radia is a general-purpose 3D magnetostatics computer code.

It was written with a primary goal to facilitate design of Insertion Devices for Synchrotron Radiation Sources. However, it has also proved its efficiency in solving many other types of 3D boundary problems of magnetostatics.

 

Current version: 4.25

This version of Radia was developed as an extension to Igor Pro (WaveMetrics).

Release date: May 2008

 

Radia is copyright European Synchrotron Radiation Facility (1997-2002)

portions copyright Synchrotron SOLEIL (2002-2008)

 

Authors:

O. Chubar (oleg.chubar@synchrotron-soleil.fr)

P. Elleaume (elleaume@esrf.fr)

J. Chavanne (chavanne@esrf.fr)

 

 

•   Radia Functions

Radia for Igor Pro is mainly a set of additional functions available in the Igor Pro macro language. These functions should be used to define 3D geometries, magnetic materials, boundary conditions, to solve problems of magnetostatics, and to display the resulting magnetic field in graphs.

 

Radia functions can be easily recognized: all of them start with "rad". The reference to these functions is available in this file; besides, it is accessible via Igor Pro Help Browser (menu "Help->Igor Help Browser", and then tab "Command Help").

 

 

radObjRecMag(P, D, M)

      wave P, D, M

 

Creates a uniformly magnetized rectangular parallelepiped block.

 

P is block's center point (wave of 3 elements);

D is array of block dimensions (wave of 3 elements);

M is magnetization vector inside the block (wave of 3 elements).

Returns an integer number referencing the object created.

 

radObjThckPgn(x, lx, P, t, M)

      variable x, lx

      wave P, M

      string t

 

Creates a uniformly magnetized extruded polygonal block.

 

x is the position of the block's center of gravity in the extrusion direction;

lx is the thickness;

P is a wave of cartesian coordinates of points describing the polygon in 2D (to be created e.g. as make/O P={{y1,z1},{y2,z2},{y3,z3},...});

t is string character defining the orientation of the extrusion axis; it can be "x", "y" or "z";

M is block's magnetization vector (wave of 3 elements).

Returns an integer number referencing the object created.

 

radObjCylMag(P, r, h, n, t, M)

      wave P, M

      variable r, h, n

      string t

 

Creates a uniformly magnetized extruded right polygonal block, which approaches cylindrical shape at large number of segments n.

 

P is a wave of 3 cartesian coordinates of the cylinder center point, to be created e.g. as

make/O P={x,y,z};

r is the cylinder base radius;

h is the cylinder height;

n is number of segments of the base polygon approximating a circle;

t is string character defining the orientation of the extrusion axis; it can be "x", "y" or "z";

M is block's magnetization vector (wave of 3 elements).

Returns an integer number referencing the object created.

 

radObjPolyhdr(P, F, L, M)

      wave P, F, L, M

 

Creates a uniformly magnetized polyhedron (closed volume limited by planes).

 

P is 2D array of cartesian coordinates of the polyhedron vertex points, to be created e.g. as

make/O P={{x1,y1,z1},{x2,y2,z2},{x3,y3,z3},...};

F is flat array of indexes of vertex points defining the polyhedron faces, to be created e.g. as

make/O P={f1i1, f1i2,..., f2i1, f2i2,...};

L is array of integer numbers equal to the numbers of vertex points in each face of the polyhedron; the order of the faces is the same as in the array F (the length of the array F is equal to the sum of elements of the array L);

M is block's magnetization vector (wave of 3 elements).

Returns an integer number referencing the object created.

 

radObjArcPgnMag(P, t1, F, A, n, t2, M)

      wave P, F, A, M

      variable n

      string t1, t2

 

Creates a uniformly magnetized finite-length arc of polygonal cross-section, which is approximated by n segment polyhedrons.

 

P is a wave of 2 cartesian coordinates defining the position of the rotation axis in the plane perpendicular to this axis, to be created e.g. as

make/O P={x,y};

t1 is string character defining the orientation of the rotation axis; it can be "x", "y" or "z";

F is array of radial and axial coordinates of vertex points of the cross-section polygon, to be created e.g. as make/O F={{r1,z1},{r2,z2},...};

A wave of 2 numbers -  initial and final azimuth angles, to be created e.g. as

make/O A={a1,a2};

n is number of segments;

t2 is string which can be either "sym" or "nosym"; depending on the value of this switch, the magnetization vectors in n sector polyhedrons either will be linked by rotational symmetry ("sym"), or will behave as independent magnetization vectors at any subsequent relaxation;

M is magnetization vector (wave of 3 elements).

Returns an integer number referencing the object created.

 

radObjMltExtPgn(P, N, H, M)

      wave P, N, H, M

 

Attempts to create a convex polyhedron or a set of convex polyhedrons based on horizontal slices, which should be convex planar polygons.

 

P is "flat" 2D array of the slice polygons' coordinates, to be created e.g. as

make/O P={{x11,y11},{x12,y12},{x13,y13},...,{x21,y21},{x22,y22},{x23,y23},...};

N is array of integer values representing numbers of points in the slice polygons, to be created e.g. as make/O N={n1,n2,n3,...};

H is array of attitudes (vertical positions) of the slice polygons, to be created e.g. as

make/O H={h1,h2,h3,...};

M is block's magnetization vector (wave of 3 elements).

Returns an integer number referencing the object created.

 

radObjMltExtRtg(P, D, M)

      wave P, D, M

 

Attempts to create one uniformly magnetized convex polyhedron or a set of convex polyhedrons based on rectangular slices. The rectangular slices are assumed to be parallel to the XY plane.

 

P is "flat" 2D array of the slice rectagles' center points (to be created e.g. as

make/O P={{x1,y1,z1},{x2,y2,z2},...});

D is "flat" array of dimensions of the slice rectangles along x and y (to be created e.g. as

make/O D={{dx1,dy1},{dx2,dy2},...});

M is block's magnetization vector (wave of 3 elements).

Returns an integer number referencing the object created.

 

radObjMltExtTri(x, lx, P, S, t1, M, t2)

      variable x, lx

      wave P, S, M

      string t1, t2

 

Attempts to create a triangulated extruded polygon block, i.e. a straight prism with its base being (possibly con-convex) 2D polygon subdivided by triangulation.

 

x is the position of the block's center of gravity in the extrusion direction;

lx is the prism height (or "thickess");

P is a wave of cartesian coordinates of points describing the polygon in 2D (to be created e.g. as make/O P={{y1,z1},{y2,z2},...});

S is array of subdivision (triangulation) parameters, to be created e.g. as

make/O S={{k1,q1},{k2,q2},...}

where k1,k2,... are, depending on the value of the option "ki->Numb|Size" numbers of parts or average sizes of segments to be produced by triangulation; q1,q2,... are the corresponding ratios of the last-to-first part lengths;

t1 is character defining the orientation of the rotation axis; it can be "x", "y" or "z";

M is block's magnetization vector (wave of 3 elements).

t2 is option string which can be "ki->Numb" (default) or "ki->Size" for the subdivision parameters to be interpreted as numbers of segments or their average lengths; "TriAngMin->..." with a real positive number in place of "..." to specify minimal angle of triangles to be produced by th etriangulation of the base polygon (in degrees, default value is 20); "TriAreaMax->..." with a real positive number in place of "..." to specify maximal area of traingles to be produced (in mm^2, not defined by default); t can contain composition of these sub-strings separated by ";", e.g.: "ki->Size;TriAngMin->25;TriAreaMax->10".

Returns an integer number referencing the object created.

 

radObjRecCur(P, D, J)

      wave P, D, J

 

Creates a current carrying rectangular parallelepiped block.

 

P is block's center point (wave of 3 elements);

D is array of block dimensions (wave of 3 elements);

J is current density vector inside the block (wave of 3 elements).

Returns an integer number referencing the object created.

 

radObjArcCur(P, R, A, h, n, t1, t2, j)

      wave P, R, A

      variable h, n, j

      string t1, t2

 

Creates a current carrying finite-length arc of rectangular cross-section.

 

P is array of 3 cartesian coordinates of the arc center point (wave of 3 elements);

R is array of 2 numbers - inner and outer radii (wave of 2 elements);

A is array of 2 numbers -  initial and final azimuth angles (wave of 2 elements);

h is height;

n is number of segments;

t1 is string which can be either "man" or "auto"; the magnetic field from the arc is then computed based on the number of segments nseg ("man"), or on the general absolute precision level specified by the functions radFldCmpCrt or radFldCmpPrc ("auto");

t2 is string defining the orientation of the arc rotation axis; it can be "x", "y" or "z";

j is azimuthal current density [T/mm^2].

Returns an integer number referencing the object created.

 

radObjRaceTrk(P, R, D, h, n, t1, t2, j)

      wave P, R, D

      variable h, n, j

      string t1, t2

 

Creates a current-carrying racetrack coil. The coil consists of four 90-degree bents connected by four straight parts of rectangular cross-section.

 

P is array of 3 cartesian coordinates of the racetrack center point (wave of 3 elements);

R is array of 2 numbers - inner and outer radii (wave of 2 elements);

D is array of 2 numbers - racetrack straight section lengths (wave of 2 elements);

h is height;

n is number of segments in the arc parts of the racetrack;

t1 is string which can be either "man" or "auto"; the magnetic field from the arc is then computed based on the number of segments nseg ("man"), or on the general absolute precision level specified by the functions radFldCmpCrt or radFldCmpPrc ("auto");

t2 is string defining the orientation of the racetrack axis; it can be "x", "y" or "z";

j is azimuthal current density [T/mm^2].

Returns an integer number referencing the object created.

 

radObjFlmCur(P, i)

      wave P

      variable i

 

Creates a filament polygonal line conductor with current. The line conductor is defined by sequence of points in 3D space.

 

P is array of cartesian coordinates of the points (to be created e.g. as

make/O P={{x1,y1,z1},{x2,y2,z2},...});

i is current.

Returns an integer number referencing the object created.

 

radObjScaleCur(n, k)

      variable n, k

 

Scales current (density) in the object n by multiplying it by k coefficient (if n is a current-carying object). If n is a container, the current (density) scaling applies to all its members.

 

n is integer number referencying an object;

k is current scaling coefficient.

Returns n.

 

radObjBckg(B)

      wave B

     

Creates a source of uniform background magnetic field.

 

B is magnetic field vector (wave of 3 elements).

Returns an integer number referencing the object created.

 

radObjCnt(N)

      wave N

     

Creates a container of magnetic field source objects.

 

N is array of reference numbers of the objects (to be created e.g. as

make/O N={n1,n2,n3,...}).

Returns an integer number referencing the object created.

 

radObjCnt0()

     

Creates an empty container.

 

Returns an integer number referencing the object created.

 

radObjAddToCnt(n0, N)

      variable n0

      wave N

     

Adds objects to the container object referenced by n0.

 

n0 is integer number referencying the container;

N is array of reference numbers of the objects to add, to be created e.g. as

make/O N={n1,n2,n3,...}.

Returns n0.

 

radObjCntSize(n)

      variable n

     

Calculates the number of objects in the container referenced by n.

 

n is integer number referencying the container.

Returns number of objects calculated.

 

radObjCntStuf(N, n0)

      wave N

      variable n0

     

Fills-in an array with reference numbers of objects present in the container n0.

 

N is array for the reference numbers of the objects in the container;

n0 is integer number referencying the container.

Returns n0.

 

radObjFullMag(P, D, M, K, n, mat, C)

      wave P, D, M, K, C

      variable n, mat

     

Creates a parallelepiped block with center point P, dimensions L and color RGB. The block is magnetized according to M, then subdivided according to {K[0],K[1],K[2]}, and added into the container n. n should be created in advance by calling the function radObjCnt.

 

P is block's center point (wave of 3 elements);

D is array of block dimensions (wave of 3 elements);

M is magnetization vector inside the block (wave of 3 elements);

K is wave of 3 subdivision numbers;

n is integer number referencying the container;

mat is integer number referencying the magnetic material;

C is array of 3 numbers from 0 to 1 specifying intensities of red, green and blue colors.

Returns an integer number referencing the object created.

 

radObjM(M, n)

      wave M

      variable n

     

Specifies coordinates of geometrical center point(s) and magnetization(s) of the object referenced by n.

 

M is array of coordinates of geometrical center point(s) and magnetization(s). If n is a container, the array includes the container members' center points and their magnetizations;

n is reference number of a magnetic field source object.

Returns n.

 

radObjDpl(n, t)

      variable n

      string t

     

Duplicates the object referenced by n.

 

n is reference number of the object to be duplicated;

t is a string, which can be "FreeSym->False", "FreeSym->True" or "". This specifies whether the symmetries (transformations with multiplicity more than one) previously applied to the object obj should be simply copied at the duplication ("FreeSym->False" or ""), or a container of new independent objects should be created in place of any symmetry previously applied to the object n. In both cases the final object created by the duplication has exactly the same geometry as the initial object n.

Returns an integer number referencing the new object - a copy of the object referenced by n.

 

radObjCutMag(N, n0, P, V, t)

      wave N, P, V

      variable n0

      string t

     

Cuts the object n0 by a plane passing through the point P normally to the vector V.

 

N is array of reference numbers of objects created by cutting of the object n0;

n0 is reference number of a 3D object to cut;

P is array of 3 cartesian coordinates of a point the cutting plane passes through;

V is array of 3 cartesian coordinates of a vector normal to the cutting plane;

t is a string which can be "Frame->Lab", "Frame->Loc" or "". This specifies whether the cuting plane is defined in the laboratory frame ("Frame->Lab" or "") or in the local frame of the object n0.

Returns number ov the objects created by the cutting.

 

radObjDivMagPln(n, S, V, t)

      variable n

      wave S, V

      string t

     

Subdivides the object n by sets of parallel planes.

 

n is reference number of a 3D object to subdivide;

S is array of main subdivision parameters, to be created e.g. as

make/O S={{k1,q1},{k2,q2},{k3,q3}}

where k1,k2,k2 are, depending on the value of the option "kxkykz->Numb|Size" numbers of parts or average sizes of objects to be produced in different directions; q1,q2,q3 are the corresponding ratios of the last-to-first part sizes;

V is array of cartesian coordinates of 3 vectors normal to the subdivision planes, to be created e.g. as: make/O V={{x1,y1,z1},{x2,y2,z2},{x3,y3,z3}}

t is options string which can be "kxkykz->Numb" (default) or "kxkykz->Size" for the subdivision parameters to be interpreted as numbers of peices or their average dimensions; "Frame->Lab", "Frame->LabTot" or "Frame->Loc" for the subdivision to be performed in the laboratory frame or in local frame of the 3D object. The action of "Frame->Lab" and "Frame->LabTot" differs only for containers: "Frame->Lab" means that each of the objects in the container is subdivided separately; "Frame->LabTot" means that all objects in the container are subdivided as one object, by the same planes. t can contain composition of these sub-strings separated by ";", e.g.:

"kxkykz->Size;Frame->LabTot".

Returns reference number of the object (container) created by subdivision of the object n.

 

radObjDivMagCyl(n, S, C, r, t)

      variable n, r

      wave S, C

      string t

     

Subdivides the object n by a set of coaxial elliptic cylinders.

 

n is reference number of a 3D object to subdivide;

S is array of main subdivision parameters, to be created e.g. as

make/O S={{k1,q1},{k2,q2},{k3,q3}}

where k1,k2,k2 are, depending on the value of the option "kxkykz->Numb|Size" numbers of parts or average sizes of objects to be produced in radial, azimuthal, and axial directions respectively; q1,q2,q3 are the corresponding ratios of the last-to-first part sizes;

C is array of cartesian coordinates of points and vectors specifying positions of subdividing coaxial elliptic cylinders in space, to be created e.g. as

make/O C={{ax,ay,az},{vx,vy,vz},{px,py,pz}}

where the point (ax,ay,az) and the vector (vx,vy,vz) define the axis of the subdividing cylinders; one of two axes of the cylinder base ellipses is exactly the perpendicular from the point (px,py,pz) to the cylinder axis;

r is the ratio of the base ellipse axes lengths;

t is options string which can be "kxkykz->Numb" (default) or "kxkykz->Size" for the subdivision parameters to be interpreted as numbers of peices or their average dimensions; "Frame->Lab", "Frame->LabTot" or "Frame->Loc" for the subdivision to be performed in the laboratory frame or in local frame of the 3D object. The action of "Frame->Lab" and "Frame->LabTot" differs only for containers: "Frame->Lab" means that each of the objects in the container is subdivided separately; "Frame->LabTot" means that all objects in the container are subdivided as one object, by the same planes. t can contain composition of these sub-strings separated by ";", e.g.:

"kxkykz->Size;Frame->LabTot".

Returns reference number of the object (container) created by subdivision of the object n.

 

radObjGeoVol(n)

      variable n

     

Computes geometrical volume of a 3D object referenced by n.

 

n is reference number of a 3D object.

Returns the volume value.

 

radObjGeoLim(D, n)

      wave D

      variable n

     

Computes cartesian coordinates of extremity points of the object n in laboratory frame.

 

D is array of coordinates of extremity points of the object n.

n is reference number of a 3D object.

Returns n.

 

radObjDrwOpenGL(n, t)

      variable n

      string t

     

Starts an application for viewing of 3D geometry of the object referenced by n. The viewer is based on the GLUT / OpenGL graphics library.

 

n is reference number of a 3D object;

t is a string specifying optional parameters. The supported options are:

"Axes->True" (default) or "Axes->False" for showing or not the axes of the Cartesian laboratory frame,

"EdgeLines->True" (default) or "EdgeLines->False" for highlighting or not the edge lines of 3D object(s),

"Faces->True" (default) or "Faces->False" for showing or not visible faces of the 3D objects.

The string t can contain any composition of these option sub-strings, separated by ";", e.g.:

"Axes->False;Faces->False".

Returns n.

 

radObjDrwQD3D(n, t)

      variable n

      string t

     

Starts an application for viewing of 3D geometry of the object referenced by n. The viewer is based on the QuickDraw 3D graphics library developed by Apple.

 

n is reference number of a 3D object;

t is a string specifying optional parameters. The supported options are:

"Axes->True" (default) or "Axes->False" for showing or not the axes of the Cartesian laboratory frame,

"EdgeLines->True" (default) or "EdgeLines->False" for highlighting or not the edge lines of 3D object(s),

"Faces->True" (default) or "Faces->False" for showing or not visible faces of the 3D objects.

The string t can contain any composition of these option sub-strings, separated by ";", e.g.:

"Axes->False;Faces->False".

Returns n.

 

radObjDrwAtr(n, C, d)

      variable n, d

      wave C

     

Applies drawing attributes - RGB color and line thickness to the object referenced by n.

 

n is reference number of a 3D object;

C is array of 3 numbers from 0 to 1 specifying intensities of red, green and blue colors;

d is line thickness parameter.

Returns n.

 

radTrfPlSym(P, V)

      wave P, V

     

Creates a symmetry with respect to plane defined by a point and a normal vector.

 

P is array of 3 numbers representing cartesian coordinates of a point in the plane;

V is array of 3 numbers representing cartesian coordinates of a vector normal to the plane.

Returns reference number of the space transformation created.

 

radTrfRot(P, V, a)

      wave P, V

      variable a

     

Creates a rotation.

 

P is array of 3 numbers representing cartesian coordinates of a point belonging to the rotation axis;

V is array of 3 numbers representing cartesian coordinates of a vector parallel to the rotation axis;

a is rotation angle in radians.

Returns reference number of the space transformation created.

 

radTrfTrsl(V)

      wave V

     

Creates a translation.

 

V is array of 3 numbers representing cartesian coordinates of the translation vector.

Returns reference number of the space transformation created.

 

radTrfInv()

     

Creates a field inversion.

 

Returns reference number of the transformation created.

 

radTrfCmbL(s1, s2)

      variable s1, s2

     

Multiplies original space transformation s1 by another transformation s2 from left.

 

s1 is reference number of the original space transformation;

s2 is reference number of another space transformation.

Returns reference number of the final space transformation - the result of the multiplication.

 

radTrfCmbR(s1, s2)

      variable s1, s2

     

Multiplies original space transformation s1 by another transformation s2 from right.

 

s1 is reference number of the original space transformation;

s2 is reference number of another space transformation.

Returns reference number of the final space transformation - the result of the multiplication.

 

radTrfMlt(n, s, m)

      variable n, s, m

     

Creates m-1 symmetry objects of the object n. Each symmetry object is derived from the previous one by applying space transformation s to it. Following this, the object n becomes equivalent to m different objects.

 

n is reference number of the original 3D object to which symmetries should be applied;

s is reference number of a space transformation;

m is multiplicity of the space transformation.

Returns reference number of the 3D object with the symmetries applied.

 

radTrfOrnt(n, s)

      variable n, s

     

Orients object n by applying transformation s to it once.

 

n is reference number of the original 3D object to which symmetries should be applied;

s is reference number of a space transformation;

Returns reference number of the 3D object with the transformation applied.

 

radTrfZerPara(n, P, V)

      variable n

      wave P, V

     

Creates an object mirror with respect to a plane. The object mirror possesses the same geometry as n, but its magnetization and/or current densities are modified in such a way that the magnetic field produced by the n and its mirror in the plane of mirroring is perpendicular to this plane.

 

n is reference number of a magnetic field source object to which the symmetry should be applied;

P is array of 3 cartesian coordinates of a point in the mirror plane;

V is array of 3 cartesian coordinates of a vector normal to the mirror plane.

Returns reference number of the final object.

 

radTrfZerPerp(n, P, V)

      variable n

      wave P, V

     

Creates an object mirror with respect to a plane. The object mirror possesses the same geometry as n, but its magnetization and/or current densities are modified in such a way that the magnetic field produced by the n and its mirror in the plane of mirroring is parallel to this plane.

 

n is reference number of a magnetic field source object to which the symmetry should be applied;

P is array of 3 cartesian coordinates of a point in the mirror plane;

V is array of 3 cartesian coordinates of a vector normal to the mirror plane.

Returns reference number of the final object.

 

radMatLin(K, M)

      wave K, M

     

Creates a linear anisotropic magnetic material.

 

K is array of 2 magnetic susceptibility values for the directions parallel and perpendicular to the easy magnetization axis;

M is array of 3 cartesian coordinates of the remanent magnetization vector.

Returns reference number of the magnetic material created.

 

radMatSatIso(D, t)

      wave D

      string t

     

Creates a nonlinear isotropic magnetic material. The dependence of the magnetization magnitude on the magnetic field strength magnitude is defined either by the formula:

M = ms1*tanh(ksi1*H/ms1) + ms2*tanh(ksi2*H/ms2) + ms3*tanh(ksi3*H/ms3)

with the constants {{ksi1,ms1},{ksi2,ms2},{ksi3,ms3}} given by the array D, or by array of pairs of real numbers {{h1,m1},{h2,m2},...}}. Both the magnetization and the magnetic field strength should be defined in Tesla.

 

D is 2D array defining the dependence of the magnetization magnitude on the magnetic field strength magnitude. The interpretation of the array D depends on the value of the string variable t.

If t is "frm", D should be interpreted as array of material constants for the formula given above, in the format:

make/O D={{ksi1,ms1},{ksi2,ms2},{ksi3,ms3}};

If t is "tab", D should be interpreted as tabulated dependence M vs H (both in Tesla):

make/O D={{h1,m1},{h2,m2},...}};

t is a string which can be either "frm" or "tab". This defines how the array D should be interpreted.

Returns reference number of the magnetic material created.

 

radMatSatLam(D, t, p, N)

      wave D, N

      string t

      variable p

     

Creates a nonlinear laminated magnetic material. The dependence of the magnetization magnitude on the magnetic field strength magnitude for the corresponding isotropic case is defined either by the formula:

M = ms1*tanh(ksi1*H/ms1) + ms2*tanh(ksi2*H/ms2) + ms3*tanh(ksi3*H/ms3)

with the constants {{ksi1,ms1},{ksi2,ms2},{ksi3,ms3}} given by the array D, or by array of pairs of real numbers {{h1,m1},{h2,m2},...}}. Both the magnetization and the magnetic field strength should be defined in Tesla.

 

D is 2D array defining the dependence of the magnetization magnitude on the magnetic field strength magnitude. The interpretation of the array D depends on the value of the string variable t.

If t is "frm", D should be interpreted as array of material constants for the formula given above, in the format:

make/O D={{ksi1,ms1},{ksi2,ms2},{ksi3,ms3}};

If t is "tab", D should be interpreted as tabulated dependence M vs H:

make/O D={{h1,m1},{h2,m2},...}};

t is a string which can be either "frm" or "tab". This defines how the array D should be interpreted;

p is the lamination stacking factor;

N is array of 3 cartesian coordinates of a vector normal to the lamination planes.

Returns reference number of the magnetic material created.

 

radMatSatAniso(Dpar, Dper)

      wave Dpar, Dper

     

Creates a nonlinear anisotropic magnetic material. The dependence of the magnetization on the magnetic field strength in the directions parallel to the easy axis is defined either by:

M = ms1*tanh(ksi1*(h-hc1)/ms1) + ms2*tanh(ksi2*(h-hc2)/ms2) + ms3*tanh(ksi3*(h-hc3)/ms3) + ksi0*(h-hc0),

or by:

M = ksi0*h,

with the constants {ksi1,ms1,hc1,ksi2,ms2,hc2,ksi3,ms3,hc3,ksi0,hc0} given by the array Dpar.

The dependence of the magnetization on the magnetic field strength in the directions perpendicular to the easy axis is defined either by:

M = ms1*tanh(ksi1*h/ms1) + ms2*tanh(ksi2*h/ms2) + ms3*tanh(ksi3*h/ms3) + ksi0*h,

or by:

M = ksi0*h,

with the constants {ksi1,ms1,ksi2,ms2,ksi3,ms3,ksi0} given by the array Dper.

At least one of the magnetization vector components should non-linearly depend on the field strength.

The direction of the easy axis should be specified at creation of a 3D object to which this material is applied.

 

Dpar is 1D array defining the material constants used in the formulae given above in the direction parallel to the easy axis, to be created e.g. as:

make/O Dpar={ksi1,ms1,hc1,ksi2,ms2,hc2,ksi3,ms3,hc3,ksi0,hc0};

Dper is 1D array defining the material constants used in the formulae given above in the direction perpendicular to the easy magnetization axis, to be created e.g. as:

make/O Dper={ksi1,ms1,ksi2,ms2,ksi3,ms3,ksi0};

Returns reference number of the magnetic material created.

 

radMatStd(t, m)

      string t

      variable m

     

Creates a pre-defined magnetic material. The material is identified by its name/formula, given by the string t (e.g. "NdFeB", "SmCo5", "Sm2Co17", "Ferrite", "XcO6", "Steel37", "Steel42", "AFK502",...).

 

t is string describing the common name of the material;

m is (optional) remanent magnetization parameter of the standard material (is taken into account if positive).

Returns reference number of the magnetic material created.

 

radMatApl(n, m)

      variable n, m

     

Applies magnetic material m to 3D object n.

 

n is reference number of the 3D object;

m is reference number of the magnetic material.

Returns n.

 

radMatMvsH(M, n, t, H)

      wave M, H

      variable n

      string t

     

Computes magnetization from magnetic field strength vector for a given magnetic material or 3D object with the material applied.

 

M is magnetization vector to be computed;

n is reference number of a magnetic material or a 3D object with magnetic material applied;

t is string specifying the component(s) of the magnetization vector to be computed (can be "Mx", "Mz",...);

H is magnetic field strength vector (in Tesla).

Returns number of magnetization components computed.

 

radRlxPre(n0, n1)

      variable n0, n1

     

Builds interaction matrix for the object n0, treating the object n1 as additional constant source of magnetic field.

 

n0 is reference number of the main object, for which the interaction matrix should be created;

n1 is reference number of another object treated as additional constant source of magnetic field (can be 0).

Returns integer number referencying the interaction matrix created.

 

radRlxMan(D, n, m, i, r)

      wave D

      variable n, m, i, r

     

Executes "manual" relaxation procedure for the interaction matrix referenced by n.

 

D is array of numbers describing the result of the relaxation;

n is reference number of the interaction matrix;

m is an integer number specifying the method of relaxation to be used;

i is an integer number specifying number of iterations to be made;

r is a real number between 0 and 1 specifying the relaxation parameter.

Returns i.

 

radRlxAuto(D, n, p, i, m, t)

      wave D

      variable n, p, i, m

      string t

     

Executes "automatic" relaxation procedure for the interaction matrix referenced by n. The relaxation stops whenever the change of magnetization (averaged over all sub-elements) between two successive iterations is smaller than p or the number of iterations is larger than i.

 

D is array of numbers describing the result of the relaxation: D[0] is average absolute change in magnetization after previous iteration over all the objects participating in the relaxation, D[1] is maximum absolute value of magnetization over all the objects participating in the relaxation, D[2] is maximum absolute value of magnetic field strength over central points of all the objects participating in the relaxation, and D[3] is actual number of iterations made. The values D[0]-D[2] are those of the last iteration;

n is reference number of the interaction matrix;

p is a real number specifying an absolute precision value for magnetization (in Tesla), to be reached by the end of the relaxation procedure;

i is an integer number specifying maximum number of iterations to be made;

m is an integer number specifying the method of relaxation to be used;

t is a string specifying optional parameters. The supported options are:

"ZeroM->True" (default) or "ZeroM->False" to specify whether the relaxation should be started by setting the magnetization values in all paricipating objects to zero, or the existing magnetization values in the objects should be used.

Returns actual number of iterations made.

 

radRlxUpdSrc(n)

      variable n

     

Updates external field data for the relaxation (to take into account e.g. changes of currents in coils, if any) without rebuilding the interaction matrix.

 

n is reference number of the interaction matrix.

Returns n.

 

radSolve(D, n, p, i, m)

      wave D

      variable n, p, i, m

     

Builds an interaction matrix for the object referenced by n and performs "autimatic" relaxation procedure. The relaxation stops whenever the change of magnetization (averaged over all sub-elements) between two successive iterations is smaller than p or the number of iterations is larger than i. The interaction matrix is deleted after the relaxation.

 

D is array of numbers describing the result of the relaxation: D[0] is average absolute change in magnetization after previous iteration over all the objects participating in the relaxation, D[1] is maximum absolute value of magnetization over all the objects participating in the relaxation, D[2] is maximum absolute value of magnetic field strength over central points of all the objects participating in the relaxation, and D[3] is actual number of iterations made. The values D[0],..., D[2] are those of the last iteration;

n is reference number of the object defining the geometry to solve;

p is a real number specifying an absolute precision value for magnetization (in Tesla), to be reached by the end of the relaxation procedure;

i is an integer number specifying maximum number of iterations to be made;

m is an integer number specifying the method of relaxation to be used;

Returns actual number of iterations made.

 

radFld(B, n, t, P)

      wave B, P

      variable n

      string t

     

Computes magnetic field created by the object n at one or many points.

 

B is array of magnetic field values (to be computed);

n is reference number of the magnetic field source object;

t is string identifying magnetic field components to be computed (e.g.: "B", "Bx", "By", "H",...);

P is 2D array of coordinates of all points where the field should be computed, to be created e.g. as:

make/O P={{x1,y1,z1},{x2,y2,z2},...}

Returns the first component of the calculated magnetic field (B[0]).

 

radFldLst(B, n, t, P1, P2, np, s)

      wave B, P1, P2

      variable n, np, s

      string t

     

Computes magnetic field created by object obj in np equidistant points along a line segment from P1 to P2; the field component is specified by the t1 input string.

 

B is array of magnetic field values (to be computed);

n is reference number of the magnetic field source object;

t is string identifying magnetic field components to be computed (e.g.: "B" or "Bx" or "By" or "H",...);

P1 is array of 3 real numbers specifying cartesian coordinates of an edge point of the line segment;

P2 is array of 3 real numbers specifying cartesian coordinates of another edge point of the line segment;

np is number of points where the magnetic field should be calculated;

s is start value for the longitudinal position.

Returns the first component of the calculated magnetic field.

 

radFldInt(I, n, t1, t2, P1, P2)

      wave I, P1, P2

      variable n

      string t1, t2

     

Computes magnetic field integral produced by the object n along a straight line specified by points P1 and P2; depending on the t1 string value, the integral is infinite ("inf") or finite ("fin"), from P1 to P2; the field integral component is specified by the t2 string. The unit of the calculated field integral is T*mm.

 

I is array of field integral value(s) (to be computed);

n is reference number of the magnetic field source object;

t1 is string specifying the type of field integral: finite ("fin") or infinite ("inf");

t2 is string identifying the field integral component(s) to be computed (e.g.: "B" or "Bx" or "By" or "Bz" or "H",...);

P1 is array of 3 real numbers specifying cartesian coordinates of a point on the integration line;

P2 is array of 3 real numbers specifying cartesian coordinates of another point on the integration line.

Returns the first component of the calculated magnetic field component.

 

radFldPtcTrj(D, n, e, D0, S, np)

      wave D, D0, S

      variable n, e, np

     

Computes transverse coordinates and their derivatives (angles) of a relativistic charged trajectory in the magnetic field produced by object referenced by n, using a Runge-Kutta integration. The charge of the particle is that of electron. All positions are in millimeters and angles in radians.

 

D is array of computed tragectory parameters;

n is reference number of the magnetic field source object;

e is particle energy in GeV;

D0 is array of 4 real numbers specifying initial transverse coordinates and angles of the trajectory: {x0,dxdy0,z0,dzdy0} (y is longitudinal coordinate);

S is array of 2 real numbers specifying limits of the longitudinal position {y1,y2};

np is number of points where the trajectory should be calculated.

Returns total number of trajectory data components calculated.

 

radFldFocPot(n, P1, P2, np)

      variable n, np

      wave P1, P2

     

Computes "focusing potential" for trajectory of relativistic charged particle in magnetic field produced by the object referenced by n. The integration is made from point P1 to point P2 with np steps.

 

n is reference number of the magnetic field source object;

P1 is array of 3 real numbers specifying cartesian coordinates of the first edge point of the integration segment;

P2 is array of 3 real numbers specifying cartesian coordinates of an edge point of the integration segment;

np is number of steps for the integration.

Returns the computed focusing potential value.

 

radFldFocKickPer(M1, M2, A1, A2, n, P, Ns, per, nper, nps, Nt, r1, np1, d1, r2, np2, d2, nh, tc)

      wave M1, M2, A1, A2, P, Ns, Nt

      string tc

      variable n, per, nper, nps, r1, np1, d1, r2, np2, d2, nh

     

Computes matrices of 2nd order kicks for trajectory of relativistic charged particle in periodic magnetic field produced by the object n. The computed kick matrices can be used in particle tracking codes.  The longitudinal integration along one period starts at point P and is done along the direction pointed by vector Ns; one direction of the transverse grid is pointed by the vector Nt, the other transverse direction is given by vector product of Nt and Ns.

 

M1 is 2D array of real numbers representing the matrix of kick values (to be computed) in the first transverse direction given by the Nt vector;

M2 is 2D array of real numbers representing the matrix of kick values (to be computed) in the second transverse direction given by vector product of Nt and Ns;

A1 is 1D array of position values in the first transverse direction where kick matrix was computed;

A2 is 1D array of position values in the second transverse direction where kick matrix was computed;

n is reference number of the magnetic field source object;

P is array of 3 real numbers specifying cartesian coordinates of the integration start point;

Ns is array of 3 real numbers specifying cartesian coordinates of a vector defining the longitudinal direction for the periodic magnetic field;

per is magnetic field period length;

nper is number of full periods of the mafnetic field;

nps is number of longitudinal points;

Nt is array of 3 real numbers specifying cartesian coordinates of a vector defining first transverse direction;

r1 is range of the transverse grid along direction given by the Nt vector;

np1 is number of points in the transverse grid along direction given by the Nt vector;

d1 is step to calculate derivative along direction given by Nt vector; d1=0 means that the step for derivative calculation is equal to the corresponding step of the transverse grid where kick matrix is computed;

r2 is range of the transverse grid along direction given by vector product of the vectors Nt and Ns;

np2 is number of points in the transverse grid along direction given by vector product of the vectors Nt and Ns;

d2 is step to calculate derivative along direction given by vector product of Nt and Ns; d2=0 means that the step for derivative calculation is equal to the corresponding step of the transverse grid where kick matrix is computed;

nh is maximum number of magnetic field harmonics to take into account;

tc is string with arbitrary comment to be inserted into resulting string t.

Returns string containing second-order kick matrices values in the format compatible with particle tracking computer codes (e.g. BETA).

 

radFldEnr(n1, n2, S)

      variable n1, n2

      wave S

     

Computes potential energy (in Joule) of the object referenced by n1 in the field created by the object referenced by n2. If all values of the wave S are 0, the function performes the computation based on absolute accuracy value for the energy (by default 10 Joule; can be modified by the function radFldCmpPrc). Otherwise, the computation is performed based on the subdivision numbers (kx=S[0], ky=S[1], kz=S[2]).

 

n1 is reference number of the object potential energy of which should be computed;

n2 is reference number of the source object creating the magnetic field;

S is array of 3 integer numbers specifying subdivision parameters for the energy computation (kx=S[0], ky=S[1], kz=S[2]). If S[0]=S[1]=S[2]=0, the function performes the computation based on absolute accuracy value for the energy (by default 10 Joule, can be modified by the function radFldCmpPrc).

Returns potential energy value (in Joule).

 

radFldEnrFrc(F, n1, n2, t, S)

      wave F, S

      variable n1, n2

      string t

     

Computes force (in Newton) acting on the object referenced by n1 in the field produced by the object referenced by n2. If all values of the wave S are 0, the function performes the computation based on absolute accuracy value for the force (by default 10 Newton; can be modified by the function radFldCmpPrc). Otherwise, the computation is performed based on the subdivision numbers (kx=S[0], ky=S[1], kz=S[2]).

 

F is array of force components (to be computed);

n1 is reference number of the object potential energy of which should be computed;

n2 is reference number of the source object creating the magnetic field;

t is string identifying the force components to be computed ("fx", "fy", "fz");

S is array of 3 integer numbers specifying subdivision parameters for the energy/force computation (kx=S[0], ky=S[1], kz=S[2]). If S[0]=S[1]=S[2]=0, the function performes the computation based on absolute accuracy value for the force (by default 10 Newton, can be modified by the function radFldCmpPrc).

Returns first force component computed.

 

radFldEnrTrq(F, n1, n2, t, P, S)

      wave F, P, S

      variable n1, n2

      string t

     

Computes torque (in Newton*mm) with respect to point P, acting on the object n1 in the field produced by the object n2. If all values of the wave S are 0, the function performes the computation based on absolute accuracy value for the torque (by default 10 Newton*mm; can be modified by the function radFldCmpPrc). Otherwise, the computation is performed based on the subdivision numbers (kx=S[0], ky=S[1], kz=S[2]).

 

F is array of torque components (to be computed);

n1 reference number of the object on which the force is acting;

n2 is reference number of the source object creating the magnetic field;

t is string identifying the force components to be computed ("tx", "ty", "tz");

P is array of 3 real numbers specifying cartesian coordinates of the point with respect to which the torque should be computed;

S is array of 3 integer numbers specifying subdivision parameters for the energy/force/torque computation (kx=S[0], ky=S[1], kz=S[2]). If S[0]=S[1]=S[2]=0, the function performes the computation based on absolute accuracy value for the torque (by default 10 Newton*mm, can be modified by the function radFldCmpPrc).

Returns first torque component computed.

 

radFldFrc(F, n0, n1)

      wave F

      variable n0, n1

     

Computes force of the field produced by the object n0 and acting on objects contoured by the shape referenced by n1. n1 can be the result of radObjRecMag (parallelepiped) or radFldFrcShpRtg (rectangle). This function uses an algorithm based on Maxwell tensor, which may not always provide high efficiency. We suggest to use the function radFldEnrFrc instead of this function.

 

F is array of force components (to be computed);

n0 is reference number of the magnetic field source object;

n1 is reference number of the sape object.

Returns first force component computed.

 

radFldCmpCrt(pb, pa, pi, pf, ptc, pta)

      variable pb, pa, pi, pf, ptc, pta

     

Sets general absolute accuracy levels for computation of magnetic field induction (pb), vector potential (pa), induction integrals along straight line (pi), field force (pf), relativistic particle trajectory coordinates (ptc) and angles (pta).

 

pb is absolute accuracy level for magnetic field induction [T];

pa is absolute accuracy level for vector potential;

pi is absolute accuracy level for magnetic field induction integrals along straight line [T*mm];

pf is absolute accuracy level for the force [N];

ptc is absolute accuracy level for particle trajectory coordinate [mm];

pta is absolute accuracy level for particle trajectory angle [r].

Returns 1 is succeeded, 0 if failed.

 

radFldCmpPrc(t)

      string t

     

Sets general absolute accuracy levels for computation of magnetic field induction (PrcB), vector potential (PrcA), induction integral along straight line (PrcBInt), field force (PrcForce), torque (PrcTorque), energy (PrcEnergy); relativistic charged particle trajectory coordinates (PrcCoord) and angles (PrcAngle). The function works according to the mechanism of string options. The name(s) of the option(s) should be: PrcB , PrcA, PrcBInt, PrcForce, PrcTorque, PrcEnergy, PrcCoord, PrcAngle.

 

t is options strings which can be equal to "PrcB->..." or "PrcA->..." or "PrcBInt->..." or "PrcForce->..." or "PrcTorque->..." or "PrcEnergy->..." or "PrcCoord->..." or "PrcAngle->...", where "..." should be replaced by the appropriate absolute accuracy level.

Returns 1 is succeeded, 0 if failed.

 

radFldUnits()

     

Shows the physical units currently in use.

 

Returns string of physical units currently in use.

 

radFldLenRndSw(t)

      string t

     

Switches "on" or "off" randomization of all the length values at creation of Radia objects. The randomization magnitude can be set by the function radFldLenTol.

 

t is string equal to either "on" or "off".

Returns 0 or 1.

 

radFldLenTol(a, r, z)

      variable a, r, z

     

Sets absolute and relative randomization magnitudes for all the length values, including coordinates and dimensions of the objects producing magnetic field, and coordinates of points where the field is computed. Optimal values of the parameters can be: r=1E-11, a=L*r, z=a, where L is the distance scale value (in mm) for the problem to be solved. Too small randomization magnitudes can result in run-time code errors.

 

a is absolute position/length randomization magnitude [mm];

r is relative position/length randomization magnitude;

z is absolute zero tolerance [mm].

Returns 1.

 

radFldFrcShpRtg(P, D)

      wave P, D

     

Creates a rectangle with central point P and dimensions D (to be used for force computation via Maxwell tensor).

 

P is array of 3 real numbers specifying cartesian coordinates of the center point;

D is array of 2 real numbers specifying dimensions of the rectangle.

Returns an integer number referencing the object created.

 

radUtiDel(n)

      variable n

     

Deletes object referenced by n.

 

n is reference number of the object to be deleted.

Returns 0.

 

radUtiDelAll()

     

Deletes all previously created objects.

 

Returns 0.

 

radUtiDmp(n)

      variable n

     

Gives information about object referenced by n.

 

n is object to show information for.

Returns string containing information about object n.

 

radUtiIntrptTim(d)

      variable d

     

Sets interruption time quanta in seconds for platforms with no pre-emptive multitasking.

 

d is interruption time quanta [s].

Returns d.

 

radUtiVer()

     

Returns the Radia version number.

 

 

•   Radia Examples

Radia for Igor Pro includes several examples describing basic types of magnetostatic computation.

 

Example#1: Uniformly Magnetized Cube    

This is the simplest Radia example. A magnetized cube is placed at position {0,0,0}. It is 1 mm in size and is magnetized according to the vector  {-0.5,1,0.7} in Tesla. The three components of the field at position {0.52,0.6,0.7} are computed. If everything goes fine, the computed components of the magnetic field should be equal or close to: {0.127365, 0.0286437, 0.0775051}.

 

Example#2: Superconducting Wiggler (Coils)    

This example consists in the creation of a set of racetrack and circular coils, plotting the coil geometry and the magnetic field produced. This geometry corresponds to a 4T superconducting wiggler. It is assumed that the reader has some experience with Igor Pro and that he has successfully run Example#1.

 

Example#3: Generic Hybrid Undulator    

This example creates and solves a simple Hybrid Undulator made with rectangular blocks.

To see the change in the peak field induced by the variation of the magnet size, edit the corresponding parameter in the beginning of the procedure RadiaExample3(). To obtain acceptable precision on the magnetic field, it is essential to increase the segmentation. This is done at the expense of memory and CPU time. The segmentation in this example has been set to np={2,2,5} for the pole and nm={1,3,1} for the magnet. This corresponds to an absolute error in the peak field of the undulator on the order of 1%. The user himself should experience consequences of increasing np and nm and see how CPU time and memory increase, and how the value of the peak field approaches a limit which is the value looked for. To do so, edit the nm or np values in the RadiaExample3() and re-execute this macro. Using segmentation which is too large may result in a memory allocation failure and even crash of the Igor Pro. It is a fact that iron pieces need much more segmentation than the magnets since the magnetization there is very sensitive to the external field.

One can also compute the Field Integral produced by such an undulator, forces on the magnets and poles, etc. One can build a wedge pole undulator by using polyhedrons or extruded polygons instead of rectangular blocks... To learn more, read the Radia documentation, make tests and develop experience.

 

Example#4: Uniformly Magnetized Polyhedron    

This example illustrates the use of a polyhedron shape by means of the "radObjMltExtPgn" function. A uniformly magnetized polyhedron is created with a magnetization of 1 Tesla. The field produced by this polyhedron is computed and shown to be uniform inside the volume of the polyhedron and equal to 2/3 Tesla as expected from an analytical integration.

It is assumed that the reader has some experience with Mathematica and that he has successfully run the Example#1.

Start the procedure RadiaExample4() and follow the instructions that may appear. If the execution seems successful, try to modify some parameters (see the Reference Guide for the explanations on the Radia functions) and re-execute the corresponding section.
